thread.title: Kyle Flood felt 'helpless,' Leonte Carroo 'hurt' as Rutgers played on
thread.title_full: Kyle Flood felt 'helpless,' Leonte Carroo 'hurt' as Rutgers played on

title: Kyle Flood felt 'helpless,' Leonte Carroo 'hurt' as Rutgers played on
text:
Kyle Flood felt 'helpless,' Leonte Carroo 'hurt' as Rutgers played on Ryan Dunleavy , @rydunleavy 4:36 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Rutgers coach Kyle Flood and wide receiver Leonte Carroo (4) celebrated side-by-side a season-opening win against Norfolk State. (Photo: Kathy Johnson) 10 CONNECT 7 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY Misery loves company, but Kyle Flood and Leonte Carroo weren’t even permitted to speak to each other. 
On the two gamedays last month that Rutgers football was without both of its biggest names because they were suspended for unrelated incidents, the head coach watched the games alone while the star receiver watched with his family. 
“It's probably the most helpless I've ever felt in 22 years of coaching,” Flood said. “To be watching your team play, you've been with them all week, you feel like you add value when you’re there, and when you can't you just feel helpless.” 
Flood returned to the public spotlight Monday and he will return to the sidelines Saturday for the first time since before the school issued a three-game suspension and a $50,000 fine on Sept. 16. Kyle Flood off suspension at Rutgers, starts with apology 
An investigation revealed Flood initiated impermissible contact with a faculty member regarding a player’s grade. Under the terms of his penalty, Flood was allowed to run the program six days a week but could not have any contact with anyone in the program on gamedays. 
Like Flood, Carroo, who was suspended Sept. 13 by his head coach, missed the games against rival Penn State and Kansas on Homecoming. He was reinstated in time to start against Michigan State after the simple assault under domestic violence charge against him were dropped. 
“I stayed at home with family and watched the games on the TV,” Carroo said. “I made sure before the game I texted every single last one of my teammates and told them something supportive and motivated them the best as I can.” 
The only other games Carroo has missed since arriving at Rutgers are the final three of his sophomore season when he was sidelined by a concussion. 
“This was definitely much harder because I wanted to be out there so much for them,” Carroo said, “but I knew I couldn’t so it was me just watching. It hurt. 
“Ultimately I knew I could sit around and I could mope and I could cry, but why not just try to motivate them more? Give them a call or something.” Kyle Flood confident no wrongs in Rutgers drug testing, recruiting 
Flood didn’t have that luxury. 
Records for Flood’s school-issued cell phone — obtained by Gannett New Jersey through an Open Public Records Act request — indicate that he received 22 messages but did not or was not able to reply to any on Sept. 19 as Rutgers lost 28-3 at Penn State. 
All but two of those phone numbers are redacted on the records. 
In fact, Flood only used the phone to make one call that entire day — a one-minute phone call to a redacted number, according to the records. 
“Really hard. Really hard,” Flood said in describing his Saturdays. “I spent the first two by myself watching the game, and then this week's game I spent with my son watching the game.” 
Flood said he apologized to his family and to his team. 
“It was a real moment of sorrow,” offensive lineman Chris Muller said. “He did something that was different — and he apologized like a man. He apologized for what we did. We all looked past it. We’re ready to go out there and go fight for him. There is a little more oomph in our step." Kyle Flood returns at Rutgers, but B1G questions remain 
Muller added, “Our leader is back.” 
The same label often is applied to the co-captain Carroo, who scored three touchdowns in a game for the fourth time in his record-setting career, to spark Rutgers in his return. 
“I thought he gave a lot of juice to the whole team,” Muller said. 
At least for the time being, a sense of normalcy may be returning to the Hale Center. It has been missing since five players were arrested two days before the season-opener and subsequently dismissed from the program. 
“These guys responded pretty well,” Carroo said. “Even when I was out, they continued to play games and not let Coach Flood, or myself or the other guys distract them at all. 
“I feel like this team is already a focused team. We’re not distracted at all. We’re not around here for accepting any moral victories, but we played hard (against Michigan State) and if we were distracted I don’t think we would’ve played as hard as we did.” 
Staff Writer Ryan Dunleavy: rdunleavy@gannettnj.com Don't miss a thing
